chapter: 1 Data Dictionary for ALSPAC data: K01MH123914
heading: 1 Data Dictionary for ALSPAC data: K01MH123914
text: book contains information data management scoring ALSPAC eating disorder associated variables, maintained EMBARK Lab. data dictionary specifically designed project - K01MH123914 - “Driven Exercise Eating Disorders: Combined Genetic Longitudinal Epidemiological Investigation.Data dictionary represents variables obtained cleaned project – complete set raw variables available ALSPAC cohort can found larger ALSPAC data dictionary.

heading: 2 Project Aims
text: Maladaptive exercise common, debilitating symptom across eating disorders (ED). 40% individuals bulimia nervosa 80% anorexia nervosa experience driven exercise. Driven exercise relates high levels ED symptoms poor ED treatment outcomes, purported early ED symptom via retrospective reports. Among EDs, maladaptive exercise associated : increased risk suicidal behavior; poor treatment outcome, disorder prognosis, quality life1,2 obsessive-compulsive traits symptoms3–5; anxiety3,6; perfectionism3; body dissatisfaction7; reward dependence2; dietary restraint2,6; anhedonia8; hypoleptinemia9,10. , maladaptive exercise hypothesized compulsive11 /addictive12 nature.Preliminary studies suggest potential role genetic factors influencing risk eating disorder feature. recently published genome-wide association study (GWAS) Eating Disorders Workgroup Psychiatric Genomics Consortium demonstrated positive genetic correlation (rg = .17) accelerometer-measured PA13, suggesting factors increase risk also operative determining general PA levels. , preliminary findings examining polygenic prediction eating disorder symptoms ALSPAC cohort supports assertion compulsive predisposition may impact symptom driven exercise, specifically. examining obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) anorexia nervosa () polygenic scores, along transdiagnostic OCD/polygenic score predictors variety eating disorder anxiety-related symtpoms early--mid adolescence, driven exercise eating disorder symptom positively predicted (least one age gender time point) three polygenic scores14Overall, existing research points towards compulsivity general propensity exercise potential risk factors driven exercise. , driven exercise may early indicator high eating disorder risk, additional investigation ALSPAC cohort found exercise weight loss driven exercise groups age 14 demonstrated higher levels ED behaviors (binge eating, fasting, purging) age 1615.Enhanced understanding driven exercise critical eating disorder field grapples designing appropriate interventions risk , treatment , remission eating disorders. High levels physical activity frequently associated positive mental physical health outcomes16–18, exercise (planned, structured, repetitive PA)19 increasingly prescribed component mental health treatment. Exercise also evidences therapeutic benefit ED treatment, including preventing loss bone density, enhancing cognitive functioning, self-regulation, social engagement, mood regulation, reducing discomfort future eating episodes20–22. result complex relationship exercise EDs, sophisticated research phenotype needed. present, know relatively little etiology DEx, including potential genetic influences symptom, relationship premorbid activity levels, manage symptom. addition, understand factors contribute substantial variability physical activity among eating disorders, portion individuals present driven exercise. Given critical need improve treatment individuals eating disorders, even -engage driven exercise, improving understanding risk symptom paramount.current line research, extend longitudinal investigation exercise weight loss driven exercise across larger developmental window (ages 14-24) ALSPAC Cohort.Aims research include:

heading: 3 The ALSPAC Cohort
text: ALSPAC Cohort23,24 established understand genetic environmental characteristics influence health development parents children. Ethical approval study granted ALSPAC Law Ethics Committee Local Ethics Committees. pregnant women living geographical area Avon, United Kingdom, expected deliver April 1, 1991 December 31, 1992, invited participate study. Children 14,541 pregnancies enrolled; 13,988 children alive 1 year. additional 913 children enrolled subsequent phases enrollment, total sample size alive 1 year 14,901. women gave informed written consent. Among twin pairs, one twin per pair randomly excluded current study.

heading: 5.1 Body Discrepancy
text: Body dissatisfaction age 10.5 years assessed using gender-appropriate Stunkard figure rating scales (FRS)25. FRS presents participants either 5 female male figures (dependent sex participant) different weights heights asks figure participant resembles figure participant desires resemble.

heading: 5.1.1 Scoring
text: Responses figures varying weight scored ‘thin’, ‘thin’, ‘average’, ‘fat’, ‘fat’ figures varying height scored ‘short’, ‘short’, ‘average’, ‘tall’, ‘tall’. body discrepancy score generated subtracting ideal body weight/height chosen current perceived body weight/height (higher scores indicate higher body dissatisfaction).

heading: 5.1.2 Key Variables
text: body_percept.128 Respondent’s perception /body shape age 10body_desire.128 Respondent’s desired body shape age 10

heading: 5.2 Thin-ideal Internalization
text: Thin-ideal internalization age 14 assessed using Ideal-Body Stereotype Scale-Revised (IBSS-R)26 Girls boys asked six questions, three three gender-specific, assessing perceived attractiveness -sex individuals based physical characteristics (e.g. ‘lean’, ‘tall’, ‘petite’).

heading: 5.2.1 Scoring
text: Items rated 5-point Likert scale ranging ‘Strongly Disagree’ (0) ‘Strongly Agree’ (4)27. ten items averaged form overall thin-ideal internalization score.

heading: 5.2.2 Key Variables
text: ti_mean.167 Mean thin-ideal internalization score age 14ti_mean.167_NAs Percent variables missing thin-ideal internalization measure

heading: 5.3 Pressure to Lose Weight/Pressure to Increase Muscle
text: Pressure lose weight increase muscle assessed age 14 using adapted version Perceived Sociocultural Pressure Scale28. Participants asked extent felt pressures friends, family, partners, media lose weight increase muscle size. Female participants asked pressures relating weight male participants asked pressures relating weight muscle.

heading: 5.3.1 Scoring
text: Response options pressure lose weight increase muscle ‘’ (1), ‘little’ (2), ‘Quite lot’ (3), ‘lot’ (4). Scores assessment averaged form average score pressure lose weight average score pressure increase muscle.

heading: 5.3.2 Key Variables
text: pressure_lose_sum.167 Sum pressure lose weight scale age 14pressure_lose_sum.167_NAs Percent variables missing pressure lose weight scalepressure_musc_sum.167 Sum pressure increase muscle scale age 14pressure_musc_sum.167_NAs Percent variables missing pressure gain muscle scale

heading: 5.4 Restrained Eating, External Eating, and Emotional Eating
text: Restrictive Eating, External Eating, Emotional Eating assessed child age 14 years Dutch Eating Behavior Questionnaire (DEBQ)29. Restrained eating addressed purposefully restricting intake regarding weight concerns. External eating addressed likelihood participant eating due external stimuli like sight smell food, regardless participant’s hunger level. Finally, emotional eating addressed often participant ate excessively experienced different emotional states.

heading: 5.4.1 Scoring
text: Depending phrasing items, responses either asked scale ‘Yes, usually want eat ’ (1), ‘Sometimes want eat ’ (2), ‘, ’ (3) scale ‘Never’ (1), ‘Occasionally’ (2), ‘Sometimes’ (3), ‘Frequently’ (4). Scores summed greater scores indicating greater likelihood engagement restrained eating, external eating, emotional eating.

heading: 5.4.2 Key Variables
text: restraint_sum.167 Sum restrained eating items age 14restraint_sum.167_NAs Percent variables missing restrained eating subscaleext_eat_sum.167 Sum external eating items age 14ext_eat_sum.167_NAs Percent variables missing external eating subscaleemo_eat_sum.167 Sum emotional eating items age 14emo_eat_sum.167_NAs Percent variables missing emotional eating subscaleemo_eat_sum_d.167 Sum dichotomous responses emotional eating itemsemo_eat_sum_d.167_NAs Percent variables missing dichotomous emotional eating subscale

heading: 5.5 Shape and Weight Concern
text: Shape Weight concern assessed age 14 using items McNight Risk Factor Survey, assesses risk protective factors development eating disorders preadolescence adolescent girls30. two items taken McKnight Survey :‘past year, happy way body looks?’‘past year, happy way body looks?’‘past year, much weight made difference feel ?’‘past year, much weight made difference feel ?’

heading: 5.5.1 Scoring
text: 4-point Likert scale used (‘unhappy’ (1) ‘’ (1) ‘happy’ (4) ‘lot/time’ (4)) assess weight shape concern. two questions summed generate continuous score.

heading: 5.5.2 Key Variables
text: wt_shape_concern.167 Continuous sum weight shape concern items age 14wt_shape_concern.167_NAs Percent variables missing weight shape items

heading: 5.6 Body Dissatisfaction
text: Body Dissatisfaction assessed ages 14, 18, 24. 11-item scale adapted satisfaction dissatisfaction body parts scale31, used several previous studies involving ALSPAC Cohort (32;33;schaumbergAnxietyDisorderSymptoms2019?;schaumbergProspectiveAssociationsChildhood2021?), given Wave 14. Among 11 items, one item differs sexes (satisfaction ‘breasts’ specified girls ‘build’ boys). Two items address overall body satisfaction weight figure, remaining items evaluate satisfaction specific body parts.Participants asked body satisfaction age 16. Wave 18 24, participants completed 1 item addressed happiness levels regarding weight shape past year.

heading: 5.6.1 Scoring
text: age 14, responses graded 5-point Likert scale ‘Extremely Satisfied’ (1) ‘Extremely Dissatisfied’ (5).age 18, participants presented four responses ranging ‘unhappy’ (1) ‘happy’ (4). age 24, participants given 5 response options ranging ‘happy’ (1) ‘completely happy’ (5).Body dissatisfaction scored using mean 11 items, higher scores indicating greater body dissatisfaction.

heading: 5.6.2 Key Variables
text: body_sat_mean.167 Body dissatisfaction mean score age 14body_sat_mean.167_NAs Percent variables missing body dissatisfaction measure age 14body_sat.222 happy respondent way body looks past year age 18body_sat.288 Degree respondent happy way body looks weighs age 24

heading: 5.7 Dieting
text: Dieting assessed ages 14, 16, 18 years.assess dieting, participants asked set questions regarding dieting strategies lose keep gaining weight actual weight loss past year. items original ALSPAC study, thesy used multiple studies assess overall level dieting adolescents34 35. question consists multiple parts aim learn extent dieting respondent taken part . first part question aims find type diet(s) length time participant engaged said diet(s) second part asks weight lost diet possible weight gain succeeding diet.

text: asked participant gone diet past year, responses range ‘Always diet’ (1) ‘never’ (5). respondent selects answer ‘never’, prompted respond long engaged diet(s) (‘less week’, ‘1-3 weeks’, ‘1-3 months’, ‘3 4 months’) type diet(s) used.participant also answers many pounds lost diet(s) , lose weight, gained weight back diet (‘, regain weight’, ‘Gained back little weight”, ’Gained back weight’, ‘Gained back weight’, ‘put lost’).

Weight perception asks participants describe current weight.Weight valuation, asked age 18, also 1-item question asked weight made difference participant sees oneself.

heading: 6 Eating Disorder Behaviors
text: Eating Disorder Behaviors Assessed Ages 14, 16, 18, 24.Scoring eating disorder behaviors completed single scoresheet, ed_behaviors_scoresheet.xlsx, resulting data frame contains eating disorder behavior variables, titled ed_behaviors cleaned dataset.

heading: 6.0.1 Binge Eating
text: Binge eating behavior evaluated using questions derived Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance Scale36 ages 14, 16, 18, 24. Questions adapted inquire previous year34 validated sample adolescents Growing Today Study37. Binge Eating Behavior ALSPAC data previously scored examined several papers14,34,38,39,micaliEatingDisorderBehaviours2017?. ages 14, 16, 18, Binge eating assessed using two-part question. Participants first asked frequency past year eating large amount food. answered yes asked follow-question asked whether felt control episodes, .e., whether stop eating even wanted stop, along five questions regarding characterization binge eating episodes (e.g. often felt guilty binge, often ate fast faster normal binge). Participants reported binge eating asked rate five binge eating symptoms (eating faster normal, stomach hurting feeling sick, eating large amounts food, hiding amount eating binge, feeling guilty binge) whether happened never, sometimes, usually. age 24, participants asked often went eating binges past year (never, <1x/mo, 1-3x/mo, 1x/wk, >1x/wk), , , whether period frequent binge eating lasted least three months.

heading: 6.0.2 Scoring
text: Scoring questions related binge eating recodes variables sensible frequencies (e.g. changing ‘’ answer represented ‘0’ increasing frequency incrementing zero) computes dichotomized versions presence vs. absence symptoms use symptom counts. Symptom sum scores, gives count number binge eating symptoms (0-5) present individual ‘sometimes’ ‘usually’ ages 14, 16, 18 years, computed.Based sum score, two additional variables based sum score. first variable computes variable notes binge eating present (‘1’) individual reports binge eating least per month two additional symptoms (Subclinical BED criteria met) ages 14, 16, 18, binge eating least per month age 24. second variable computes variable notes full threshold Binge Eating Disorder criteria met (binge eating weekly plus three additional psychological symptoms 14-18; weekly binge eating lasting three months per age 24).

heading: 6.0.3 Key Variables
text: ‘x’ represents age assessment following variables:binge_freq_o.x - frequency binge eating timepointbinge_sx_sum.x - Number binge eating psychological symptomsbinge_sub_criteria_met.x - dichotomous variable indicating whether subthreshold binge eating disorder symptoms metbinge_criteria_met.x - dichotomous variable indicating whether full threshold binge eating disorder symtpoms met
